<p><object data="http://www.twitch.tv/widgets/archive_embed_player.swf" height="378" id="clip_embed_player_flash" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="420"><param name="movie" value="http://www.twitch.tv/widgets/archive_embed_player.swf"><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"><param name="allowNetworking" value="all"><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"><param name="flashvars" value="title=Let%2527s%2Bdo%2Ba%2B100%2525%2BIVA%2BMun%2BLanding%2521%2BKerbal%2BSpace%2BProgram%2Bwith%2BNO%2BRELOADING&channel=overloadut&auto_play=false&start_volume=25&archive_id=554672051"></object><br/>Say hello to <a href="http://www.twitch.tv/overloadut"><strong>OverloadUT</strong></a>, the newest member of <a href="http://www.twitch.tv/ksptv"><strong>KSP-TV</strong></a>. Spend some time with him in the cockpit during a 100% IVA Mun landing. Get to know his intrepid Kerbal crew and come back every Monday at 11 PM EDT for a taste of <em>KSP</em>, hardcore style.</p>
I was really surprised how fun that mission ended up being. Big thanks to the developers of both the ALCOR pod and RasterPropMonitor for making this possible
Would probably have been much easier if you had set your chutes correctly in the first place
